title: Getting Started
text:
What this class is for:

Learning computational skills to be successful in modern research
Developing a software package from scratch for your research



This class is only intended for MS and PhD students working on thesis/dissertation research.

title: Getting Started
text:
What this class isn‚Äôt for:

Learning how to program in Python
Those who aren‚Äôt comfortable doing open-ended, self-directed work.



Though you will learn more about programming and Python, you absolutely need to have some skills already.

title: Getting Started
text:
Motivation
Nearly all research relies on software‚Äîeven experimental‚Äîbut researchers don‚Äôt get trained in best practices in the same way as experimental methods.

title: Getting Started
section: What are we going to learn about?
text:
What are we going to learn about?

Computational environment management
Version control
Collaborative software development
Structuring programs
Working with files
Improving performance, parallelization
Reproducible research
Writing about software, documentation
Sharing software openly, copyright

title: Getting Started
text:
Project
Most of your work in the class will be centered around a project developing a new software package for your research.
Assignments will focus on development stages for your software package.
First assignment: project proposal, due January 17.

title: About
text: About this site

title: Managing your computational environment
section: Power of Python for research comes from rich ecosystem of third-party packages
text:
Power of Python for research comes from rich ecosystem of third-party packages

These include general numerical and scientific tools like NumPy, SciPy, and Pandas, and domain-specific software like Cantera. You should rely on mature packages that provide useful features when possible‚Äîdon‚Äôt reinvent the wheel!


But, each software package has its own set of dependencies, and might require a specific version of some other package (like when a newer version breaks or changes some functionality).

title: Managing your computational environment
section: Your results may depend on the specific versions and combination of packages you have installed.
text:
Your results may depend on the specific versions and combination of packages you have installed.

This is particularly important for research analysis.

title: Managing your computational environment
section: üö® As a rule, don‚Äôt install packages into your global environment!
text:
üö® As a rule, don‚Äôt install packages into your global environment!

‚Ä¶ even if the documentation says pip install x

title: Managing your computational environment
text:
Best practice: use virtual environments

Virtual environments are lightweight installations of packages in a particular location (like in your working directory or project project) that build on top of your system Python installation.
Virtual environments isolate the set of dependencies for a project or package from each other, and from your system configuration.
These are intended to be easy to set up, disposable, and replaceable.

title: Managing your computational environment
section: Creating and activating a virtual environment
text:
Creating and activating a virtual environment
python3 -m venv .venv

This creates a new directory .venv with:


.venv/bin with link to Python, pip, and activation scripts; and
.venv/lib/site-packages where packages will be installed.

title: Managing your computational environment
text:
Installing packages
pip install <package>

title: Managing your computational environment
text:
pip family
Tools that all work similarly to venv:

venv: comes with Python, simple
virtualenv: installable package with same interface as venv, but faster and with more options
uv: written in Rust and extremely fast

title: Managing your computational environment
text:
Conda family

Conda is an open-source tool for managing virtual environments across your system, originally designed for Python package management but now supports a wide range of software (e.g., compiled C++ dependencies).


Virtual environments created with Conda are not location-dependent like venv, but the same approach applies: do not install in the base/default environment.


Conda is recommended if you expect to need non-Python dependencies.

title: Managing your computational environment
text:
conda config --set auto_activate_base false  # turn off the default environment
conda env create -n some_name  # or use paths with `-p`
conda activate some_name
conda deactivate

title: Managing your computational environment
text:
Conda-based package managers
Some alternatives to conda exist and offer some advantages, including speed:

Miniconda: minimal Conda installation without all the packages that come with the full Anaconda distribution
Pixi: fast, Rust-based package manager and workflow tool Some other
Micromamba: tiny version of Mamba, statically linked C++ binary

title: Managing your computational environment
text:
These include general numerical and scientific tools like NumPy, SciPy, and Pandas, and domain-specific software like Cantera. You should rely on mature packages that provide useful features when possible‚Äîdon‚Äôt reinvent the wheel!


But, each software package has its own set of dependencies, and might require a specific version of some other package (like when a newer version breaks or changes some functionality).





This is particularly important for research analysis.













Virtual environments are lightweight installations of packages in a particular location (like in your working directory or project project) that build on top of your system Python installation.
Virtual environments isolate the set of dependencies for a project or package from each other, and from your system configuration.
These are intended to be easy to set up, disposable, and replaceable.



On a Mac or Linux machine, I recommend using the built-in venv module to create a virtual environment for your work, then install inside that using the pip installer.
On Windows, your best bet is probably the Anaconda Distribution. Anaconda comes with hundreds of scientific packages already, and also lets you set up system-wide virtual environments.

title: Managing your computational environment
text:

But, each software package has its own set of dependencies, and might require a specific version of some other package (like when a newer version breaks or changes some functionality).

title: Managing your computational environment
text: This is particularly important for research analysis.

title: Managing your computational environment
text:
Virtual environments are lightweight installations of packages in a particular location (like in your working directory or project project) that build on top of your system Python installation.
Virtual environments isolate the set of dependencies for a project or package from each other, and from your system configuration.
These are intended to be easy to set up, disposable, and replaceable.



On a Mac or Linux machine, I recommend using the built-in venv module to create a virtual environment for your work, then install inside that using the pip installer.
On Windows, your best bet is probably the Anaconda Distribution. Anaconda comes with hundreds of scientific packages already, and also lets you set up system-wide virtual environments.

title: Managing your computational environment
section: Creating and activating a virtual environment
text:
Creating and activating a virtual environment
python3 -m venv .venv

This creates a new directory .venv with:


.venv/bin with link to Python, pip, and activation scripts; and
.venv/lib/site-packages where packages will be installed.



To activate the environment, source the activation script:

source .venv/bin/activate






Tip



Try this yourself. .venv/bin will be added to your PATH, and your shell will usually indicate you are ‚Äúin‚Äù a virtual environment.



To leave the virtual environment, run the deactivate function:

deactivate






Note



Closing/terminating your shell will automatically deactivate the virtual environment, and you‚Äôll need to manually activate whenever you start a new session.

title: Managing your computational environment
text:
Installing packages
pip install <package>

title: Managing your computational environment
text:
pip family
Tools that all work similarly to venv:

venv: comes with Python, simple
virtualenv: installable package with same interface as venv, but faster and with more options
uv: written in Rust and extremely fast


In addition, there are project management tools that both handle environments, packaging, production, etc.:

Hatch
Poetry
Pipenv


These work a bit differently, but can be quite powerful particularly for locking specific versions of dependencies. Consider returning to these when we are thinking about packaging and distribution.

title: Managing your computational environment
text:
Conda family

Conda is an open-source tool for managing virtual environments across your system, originally designed for Python package management but now supports a wide range of software (e.g., compiled C++ dependencies).


Virtual environments created with Conda are not location-dependent like venv, but the same approach applies: do not install in the base/default environment.


Conda is recommended if you expect to need non-Python dependencies.

title: Managing your computational environment
text:
conda config --set auto_activate_base false  # turn off the default environment
conda env create -n some_name  # or use paths with `-p`
conda activate some_name
conda deactivate

title: Managing your computational environment
text:
Conda-based package managers
Some alternatives to conda exist and offer some advantages, including speed:

Miniconda: minimal Conda installation without all the packages that come with the full Anaconda distribution
Pixi: fast, Rust-based package manager and workflow tool Some other
Micromamba: tiny version of Mamba, statically linked C++ binary

title: Introduction to version control with Git
text:
Backing up changing files
Storing and accessing an annotated history of changes
Managing the merging of changes between different change sets







Image credit: Jorge Cham, PhD Comics






 important_code.py


 important_code-2.py


 important_code-fix.py


 important_code-final.py


 important_code-final-4Apr.py





 important_code.py


 important_code.py


 important_code.py


 important_code.py


 important_code.py





Centralized:


Concurrent Version System (cvs)
Subversion (svn)
Perforce (p4)


Distributed:


Decentralized CVS (dcvs)
mercurial (hg)
bazaar (bzr)
Git (git)






Git is a knife whose handle is also a knife. ‚Äì Philip Guo





Image credit: xkcd

title: Introduction to version control with Git
text:
$ git --help

$ git config --global user.name "Kyle Niemeyer"
$ git config --global user.email "kyle.niemeyer@oregonstate.edu"
$ git config --global core.editor "vim"
crumbs: Introduction to version control with Git

title: Introduction to version control with Git
text:
~ $ mkdir analysis_code
~ $ cd analysis_code

~/analysis_code $ git init
Initialized empty Git repository in ~/analysis_code/.git/
crumbs: Introduction to version control with Git

title: Introduction to version control with Git
text:
~/analysis_code $ ls
~/analysis_code $ ls -A
.git

~/analysis_code $ cd .git && ls -A
HEAD    config    description    hooks    index    info    logs






Tip



Try this yourself.
crumbs: Introduction to version control with Git

title: Introduction to version control with Git
text:
Adding files
~/analysis_code $ touch README.md
~/analysis_code $ git add README.md
~/analysis_code $ git status






Tip



Try this yourself.
crumbs: Introduction to version control with Git

title: Introduction to version control with Git
text:
Committing changes

Snapshot of repository = revision


Committing a revision:


Saves current state with a unique ID (hash)
Names you as the author
Allows you to add a message

~/analysis_code $ git commit






Tip



Try this yourself.
crumbs: Introduction to version control with Git

title: Introduction to version control with Git
text:
Options to save time
~/analysis_code $ git commit -m "This is my message"
~/analysis_code $ git commit -am "This is my message 
                  committing all changes"
crumbs: Introduction to version control with Git

title: Introduction to version control with Git
text:
Commit messages

Bad commit message:

Fixed bug

Better commit message:

Fixed bug in mass calculation

Due to incorrect density value, mass was being calculated
orders of magnitude larger than it should. The correct value
of density fixed this problem.




Image credit: xkcd
crumbs: Introduction to version control with Git

title: Introduction to version control with Git
text:
Viewing history and differences
~/analysis_code $ git log
~/analysis_code $ git diff
crumbs: Introduction to version control with Git

title: Introduction to version control with Git
text:
Undoing work

Un-add a file that has been staged:

~/analysis_code $ git restore --staged <filename>

Reset all tracked files to previous commit:

~/analysis_code $ git reset [mode] [commit]

Remove uncommitted changes:

~/analysis_code $ git checkout -- <filename>
crumbs: Introduction to version control with Git

title: Introduction to version control with Git
text:
Branches
~/analysis_code $ git branch
* main

~/analysis_code $ git branch experimental
~/analysis_code $ git branch
  experimental
* main

~/analysis_code $ git branch new
~/analysis_code $ git branch
  experimental
* main
  new

~/analysis_code $ git branch -d new
~/analysis_code $ git branch
  experimental
* main

~/analysis_code $ git switch experimental
~/analysis_code $ git branch
* experimental
  main
crumbs: Introduction to version control with Git

title: Introduction to version control with Git
text:
Merging branches
~/analysis_code $ git switch main
~/analysis_code $ git merge experimental
~/analysis_code $ git log
crumbs: Introduction to version control with Git

title: Introduction to version control with Git
text:
Types of version control

Centralized:


Concurrent Version System (cvs)
Subversion (svn)
Perforce (p4)


Distributed:


Decentralized CVS (dcvs)
mercurial (hg)
bazaar (bzr)
Git (git)
